channel.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
channel.description: i under stand how the triangle works just how to solve the equation such as (2x-y)^6 if you forgot the pyramid its like this 1 1 1 1 2 1 1 3 3 1 1 4 6 4 1 1 5 10 10 5 1 and so on. plz help i was absent when this was taught and it was on the last day of school before exam week

item.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Calculus is difficult only because everything is new…you have to admit that concepts like algebra and trigonometry were difficult when you first started, but once you get into it further it makes more sense and becomes easier. Same applies to calculus. Actually, that strange part is that the most difficult part of calculus (and the area where one is bound to make the most mistakes) is when doing the algebra

Good job on the exam btw. I think I’d have to wait til next semester to get a grade for my exam, but I’m fairly sure I passed the course with an A, so I’m happy

item.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
item.dc:creator: @leader leader
item.description:
@leader wrote:

Calculus is a difficult course. However, once you understand it, it’s simple. I think you will probably take Pre-Calculus first. I love math.

If your thinking about taking Calculus, then make sure you have a strong background in algebra and trigonometry. In order to do well, your going to need to pay attention and be alert.

Also, if you need to review or if you don’t understand the material in Algebra then go to this website. www.Hotmath.com, it is a good website that will help you understand the particular algebra topic, there are tests on there too.

My finals start on Wednesday.

o i c! the pascals triangle is a shortcut for the binomial theorum. It just gives the basic cooeficeints for a and b. and when you plug the x and y values you just multiply the coeffeciants and simplify the problem. I get it now ty!! (its the night b4 exams)

item.source: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle

item.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Well, if you can work this out more easily with Pascal’s triangle, lets first start by taking the relevant line:
(a + b)[sup]6[/sup] 1 6 15 20 15 6 1

Basically, that means:
(a + b)[sup]6[/sup] = 1a[sup]6[/sup]b[sup]0[/sup] + 6a[sup]5[/sup]b[sup]1[/sup] + 15a[sup]4[/sup]b[sup]2[/sup] + 20a[sup]3[/sup]b[sup]3[/sup] + 15a[sup]2[/sup]b[sup]4[/sup] + 6a[sup]1[/sup]b[sup]5[/sup] + 1a[sup]0[/sup]b[sup]6[/sup]

Note that taking anything to the 0th power returns 1 (with the exception of 0, but we’ll leave that for now). So, simplified:

(a + b)[sup]6[/sup] = a[sup]6[/sup] + 6a[sup]5[/sup]b + 15a[sup]4[/sup]b[sup]2[/sup] + 20a[sup]3[/sup]b[sup]3[/sup] + 15a[sup]2[/sup]b[sup]4[/sup] + 6ab[sup]5[/sup] + b[sup]6[/sup]

Because a = 2x and b = -1y, you also have to apply the appropriate exponent to the coefficient. So, just by plugging everything in (and remembering that when y had an odd exponent the entire term becomes negative), you get the answer as I have above

Read full topic

item.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
item.dc:creator: @13om13e12 13om13e12
item.description:
@13om13e12 wrote:

i know how to work the pascals triangle and figure the lines. I also understand how the lines relate to the binomial therom. such as
(a+b)^0 1
(a+b) 1 1
(a+b)^2 1 2 1
(a+b)^3 1 3 3 1
(a+b)^4 1 4 6 4 1
(a+b)^5 1 5 10 10 5 1
(a+b)^6 1 6 15 20 15 6 1
(a+b)^7 1 7 21 35 35 21 7 1
(a+b)^8 1 8 28 56 70 56 28 8 1

the main part i dont understand is how you use this information to apply to the original problem.
if i start to solve the problem (2x-y)^6 i see that a=2x b=-y. from what i learned about the pyrimid am i supposed to multiply the cooificiants to the row i need. so it would be
2 12 32 40 as the numbers. and in the algebra 2 book there was also information on 2 as being ^0 and ^6 and you test them all out or something. this is where i get very confused. plz post

Read full topic
item.source: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle

item.title: Im taking an exam tomarro for algebra 2 i got confused on the pascels triangle
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Pascal’s triangle is simply a “geometric” form of the binomial theorem…so if you know that, you can solve any problem like this. Tbh, I don’t know a way to continue Pascal’s triangle without using the binomial theorem (I’m sure there’s a way tho).

Since we don’t know the form for a power of 6, we can use the general binomial theorem formula (which can be seen here as I have no clue how I’d write it here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_theorem)

So for our 6 iterations, we get the results:
0: y[sup]6[/sup]
1: -12xy[sup]5[/sup]
2: 60x[sup]2[/sup]y[sup]4[/sup]
3: -160x[sup]3[/sup]y[sup]3[/sup]
4: 240x[sup]4[/sup]y[sup]2[/sup]
5: -192x[sup]5[/sup]y
6: 64x[sup]6[/sup]

You can add em together and get the answer Hope that’s right, lol. I don’t know if you covered this though, so if you know how to work out the next line of pascal’s triangle, you can just use those coefficients. You have to remember, though, to consider the coefficient for x in this case before working it out.

Read full topic
